sections.heading: FULL CRITICAL REVIEW
sections.text: Roles of particle size, shape and surface chemistry of mesoporous silica nanomaterials on biological systems

sections.heading: N. Hao∗1,2, L. Li1 and F. Tang∗1
sections.text: The successful application of mesoporous silica nanomaterials (MSNs) in biomedical fields requires careful consideration of their spatial dimensions, biofunctionality, specific cellular uptake efficiency, biocompatibility and targeting delivery efficacy. A deep understanding of the interactions between MSNs and biological systems is thus of significant importance. To this end, over the past few decades, studies aimed at synthesis of MSNs with controlled size, shape and surface chemistry properties and exploring the roles of these properties on in vitro and in vivo biological performance have been conducted. These studies provide new and foundational information for engineering the next generation of mesoporous silica-based nanoscale devices. This review highlights the current progress on the controlled synthesis of size, shape and surface chemistry tuneable MSNs, emphasises the roles of size, shape and surface chemistry on biological systems with a special focus on the direct comparison studies, and discusses the emerging design paradigm for building mesoporous silica-based particulate systems. Keywords: Size, Shape, Surface chemistry, Mesoporous silica, Nanomaterials, Nanobiotechnology

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Nanobiotechnology is a novel and promising field of science, emerging at the intersection of chemistry, materials, physics and biology. Particularly, the utilisation of nanomaterials in biological systems has been recognised as one of the fastest-growing and most exciting areas, and has been extensively explored.1–5 In this context, building nanomaterials with well-defined physiochemical properties, including size, shape and surface chemistry, for nanobiotechnology is critically important. Recent advances in nanofabrication techniques have successfully created various kinds of nanostructures, imparting momentum to the research and development of nanobiotechnology and opening up new avenues in biological studies. Among various biomaterials, mesoporous silica nano-
materials (MSNs) are a type of important structures with many attractive characteristics, such as rich fabrication methods, tuneable physiochemical properties, abundant porosity, high surface area and good chemical and mechanical stability. Therefore, since their discovery,6
researchers have paid a great attention to explore the interactions of MSNswith biological systems. Theoretical and experimental studies regarding the rational design of
mesoporous silica-based carrier system have led to many interesting findings in recent years, especially the roles of particle size, shape and surface chemistry of MSNs on the in vitro and in vivo biological performance. By independently altering one parameter while others are kept constant, researchers systematically established the effect of each parameter of MSNs on biological systems, which enable us to tell if one parameter is responsible for a specific biological response. These kinds of studies provide important tools that help in engineering rational mesoporous silica-based nanodevices for biological applications (Fig. 1). In this review, by paying particular attention to the phy-
siochemical properties of MSNs, we summarise recent research progress in the controlled synthesis and biological behaviour investigation of size, shape and surface chemistry tuneable MSNs. Briefly, in the following sections, we first introduce methods of synthesising MSNs with different size, shape and surface chemistry. Then we summarise typical examples that focused on the roles of size, shape and surface chemistry on biological systems. In the final section, we discuss emerging design paradigms for building mesoporous silica-based particulate systems. It is noted that besides particle size, shape and surface chemistry, other parameters (such as pore size and shape, surface area ratio, dispersibility and zeta potential) are also important for evaluating the biological performance of nanomaterials. A comprehensive understanding of the roles of physiochemical properties of MSNs on biological systems might help to design rationale-based nanoparticles for theranostic applications. 1Chinese Academy of Sciences, Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry, Beijing 100190, P. Control of particle size, shape and surface chemistry properties

sections.heading: Size control
sections.text:
MSNs are generally synthesised by a surfactant-directing method under basic, acidic or neutral conditions.7 Silica precursors are first hydrolyzed and then combined with the surfactant micelles by either electrostatic force or hydrogen bond interaction to form a liquid-crystal mesophase.6 The transformation of mesophase occurs during the hydrolysis and cocondensation of silica precursors. The formation of surfactant micelles, the interaction between surfactants and silica precursors and the rate of hydrolysis and cocondensation of silica species directly affect the genesis and evolution of mesophase. Given these facts, researchers have developed a series of
strategies to realise the size control of MSNs, such as the regulation of pH,8–12 temperature,13,14 the concentration and molar ratios of surfactants,9,11,15,16 silica precursor types,17 and the molar ratios of reactants.18 By precise control of the above reaction conditions, the particle size of yielded MSNs can be varied from tens of nanometers to micrometers (Fig. 2).

sections.heading: Shape control
sections.text: Along with size, particle shape is another interesting design parameter that should be taken into consideration.19,20 However, due to limited availability of strategies and techniques, the research and development of different-shaped MSNs has relatively lagged behind. To date, spherical materials have been extensively reported because of their relative ease of fabrication, whereas, the fabrication methods of non-spherical mesoporous silica materials are still in their relative infancy.21,22 Here, we will overview recent progress on the fabrication of several typical non-spherical materials, including rod, ellipsoid, film, platelet, sheet and cube.

sections.heading: Rod
sections.text:
Among the non-spherical MSNs, rod-shaped particles with long-range pore channels have been relatively extensively studied. By carefully choosing the reaction conditions and components, researchers have already developed a series of rod-shaped mesoporous silica
particles with aspect ratios (ARs) from 1 to 10 or even greater. Based on the classical sol-gel reaction system, the synthetic strategies to form rod-shaped particles include the regulation of the catalyst types and amounts,23–26 temperature,24,27 stirring rate,28 the molar ratios of cosurfactants,29–31 surfactant concentration,32 the molar ratios of reactants,33–36 and the introduction of organoalkoxysilane precursors.37–39 By the aid of these rich fabrication systems, rod-shaped mesoporous silica particles with tuneable ARs, high pore volume, ordered long-range pore channels and well-defined rigid surface can be obtained in a controlled and efficient way (Fig. 3a). It is noted that, as a requirement for visualisation and
tracking in biological systems, fluorescent rod-shaped materials have attracted considerable attention and developed rapidly in recent years. There are two general strategies to fabricate fluorescent rod-shaped MSNs, i.e. postsynthesis grafting and cocondensation methods (Fig. 3b). The former method is realised by immobilising the reactive fluorophore on the as-synthesised particle surface, and the latter cocondensation method can dope the fluorescent moieties during the synthesis process. Comparatively, the cocondensation method exhibits many superior features in biological applications, such as straightforward synthesis, evenly distributed fluorophores throughout the entire material and high fluorescence stability due to the protective role of silica overlayer. However, there are also certain adverse effects coming from the cocondensation method, such as pore entrance blocking and a partial loss of the mesoporous structure. Generally, fluorescent rod-shaped MSNs can be yielded by the introduction of fluorophore-conjugated organoalkoxysilane.40,41 The ARs and particle size of fluorescent MSNs can be also well controlled by tuning the surfactant and catalyst concentrations, respectively.42–44
To explore and expand their biological applications, researchers have also paid great attention on creating rod-shaped MSNs with special hollow void space and mesoporous shell layer (Fig. 3c). Compared to hollow spherical counterparts, hollow rod-shaped MSNs possess lighter mass weight, larger porous capacity and relatively more abundant outstretch pore channels.45 The formation of hollow rod-shaped MSNs can be mainly concluded to three categories: (1) Hard template method. This method

usually involves several major steps, including the synthesis of hard templates, surface functionalisation for forming mesoporous silica shell layer and selective removal of templates. In this case, commonly used sacrificial templates for obtaining hollow RMSNs include gold nanorod,46 calcium carbonate,47 Gd(OH)3 nanorod,48 nickel nanorod,49 carbon nanotubes,50 porous membranes,51,52 and cellulose.53 (2) Soft template method. Compared to hard template method, soft template method does not need complicated synthetic procedures and the template removal process is relatively straightforward. To date, the established soft templates are bacteria,54 flagella,55 pili,56 organic gel,57 virus,58 lipid,59 DNA,60 and other bio-templates.61 (3) Self-template method. The typical advantage of this method over hard and soft template methods is that there is no need for an ‘extra’ template, which simplifies the fabrication procedures and reduces cost. Surface protected etching and selective etching are two common ways for simple, effective and scalable synthesis of hollow rodshaped MSNs.62

sections.heading: Ellipsoid
sections.text:
Anisotropic ellipsoid-shaped particles have recently gained particular interest because their colloidal behaviour such as Brownian motion and maximum packing can be tuned systematically through changing the AR of their axes. In addition, ellipsoid-shaped particles have already shown great promise in the design of drug carrier systems.63,64
However, the controlled synthesis of ellipsoid-shaped MSNs is still a big challenge because of the minimisation of surface free energy that usually favours general spherical shapes.Recent advances in theunderstandingand control of
sol-gel process have made great progress to the production of ellipsoid-shaped mesoporous silica nanostructures. According to the pore channels’ orientations, ellipsoid-
shaped MSNs can be divided to two main categories, i.e. particles with mesoporous channels running along the long axis and particles with mesoporous channels running along the short axis. The former type of ellipsoid-shaped MSNs has been rarely reported, but one possible way of note is to use the organic–inorganic cooperative assembly strategy in the presence of inorganic salt and cosolvent.65
The latter type of ellipsoid-shaped MSNs with relatively short channels has attracted a great attention because they are more favourable for the mass transfer applications. The established systems for producing this kind of nanomaterials include the introduction of cosurfactant,66,67 organoalkoxysilane,68 cosolvent to form water/ oil system,69,70 neutralisation method,71 and sacrificial micro-emulsion droplets template method (Fig. 4a).72
Similar to hollow rod-shaped MSNs, hollow ellipsoidshaped counterparts can be also formed via: (1) Hard template method. This method generally uses ellipsoidtype haematite or β-FeOOH nanoparticles as templates, after coating with silica layer, the templates are then selectively etched out in acidic solution to produce hollow ellipsoid-shaped nanostructures.73,74 (2) Soft template method. This method is rarely used, there is a cosurfactant strategy using tetrapropylammonium hydroxide and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide for direct synthesis of hollow ellipsoid-shaped MSNs.75 (3) Self-template method. This method is generally realised using as-prepared ellipsoid-shaped MSNs, surface protective agents (such as polyvinylpyrrolidone) and weak bases (such as NaBH4 and ammonia) (Fig. 4b). 70,76

sections.heading: Film
sections.text:
In recent years, film-shaped MSNs have attracted a lot of interests because of their specific applications in biomedical implants, optoelectronic devices, sensors and functional membranes.77 It thus makes great sense to synthesise film-shaped mesoporous silica that have ordered mesostructures and high porosity, yet are mechanically strong enough and allow selective but free transportation of materials through the films. Generally, using glass or silica wafer as solid substrate,
film-shaped MSNs can be formed by air–liquid interfaces assembly,78,79 spin-/dip-coating methods,80,81 or the evaporation-induced self-assembly approach.82 However, because the surfactantmicelles always tend to orient parallel to substrates to reduce the surface energy at interfaces, the obtained film products from these strategies are usually composed ofmesochannels that are oriented parallel to the film surface.83 For obtaining well-defined film-shaped MSNs with perpendicularly aligned channels, a series of established systems were applied in recent studies, which included self-assembly of block copolymers or gemini surfactants with organosilane,84,85 employment of electric fields,86 magnetic fields,87 electrochemical assistance,88 nanophase separation of eutectic materials,89 Stöber approach,90 surface modification for confinement effects,91 π–π interaction of template molecules,92 and cosurfactant system.93 The resulting materials have a typical mesostructure with channels normal to the film surface (Fig. 5).

sections.heading: Platelet/sheet
sections.text:
Only a handful of studies have been reported on the synthesis of platelet- and sheet-shaped MSNs. Nearmicrometer scale platelet- and sheet-shaped mesoporous silica structures with perpendicular channels of open ends would provide new insights for biomedical applications due to their short pore channel length and thus easy access. The expected shorter channel length would lead to relatively faster materials transport which is important for the immobilisation and easy release of theranostic agents. In light of researchers’ philosophy, platelet-shaped
MSNs with high accessibility of mesoporous channels were achieved by several unique strategies, such as lowtemperature synthesis with additions of heptane and

Compared to platelet-shaped structures, the synthesis of stretchable and flexible sheet-shaped mesoporous silica materials is even more difficult. And the product yields are relatively low owing to the limitations of the fabrication methods adopted. The established systems for the formation of sheet-shaped MSNs are generally reliant on the introduction of cosurfactant100–102 or cosolvent.103

sections.heading: Cube
sections.text:
Cube-shaped MSNs are one kind of fascinating colloids, which allow the formation of dense and close-packed
assemblies architectures. Therefore, since their discovery, these porous silica particles are of great interest as building blocks for surgical implant, regenerative medicine and nanocatalyst. Cube-shaped mesoporous silica nanostructures are generally synthesised via hard template method (Fig. 7a). The commonly used templates include

sections.heading: Surface chemistry control
sections.text:
One of the most advantageous properties of MSNs is their ease of functionalisation with a variety of moieties in different regions of the particle, including the external and internal surfaces, pore entrance and pore wall (Fig. 8). The introduction of functional moieties makes MSNs highly versatile and enables them to perform specialised roles. Accordingly, avariety of available instruments, such as infrared, Raman, Zeta potential, dynamic light scattering, nuclear magnetic resonance and thermogravimetric analyses, are employed to characterise the incorporation of the functionalities.112 Generally, the density of silanol groups on mesoporous silica surface is around three groups per nm2, which corresponds to approximately 5 mmol g−1 for MSNs with an average surface area of 1000 m2 g−1.113 The amount of functional moieties that is usually introduced on the surface of MSNs ranges from 0.1 to 3 mmol g−1. In this section, we will describe functional methods of each particle region separately.
Functionalisation of external and internal surfaces
A distinctive property of mesoporous silica structures is that they have two well-defined surfaces: an external and an internal one. The differences between these two surfaces have proven to be relevant for a variety of phenomena. The functionalisation of the mesoporous silica surfaces is usually realised using organoalkoxysilane reagents. These reagents can be incorporated into mesoporous silica structures by two different approaches as mentioned above, namely post-synthesis grafting and cocondensation methods. The differences between these two methods of functio-
nalisation can be revealed by a series of techniques, such as nitrogen sorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, reaction kinetics and confocal microscopy. Generally, functional groups are less homogeneously dispersed when grafted than when cocondensed. Most of the functional groups in the grafted materials are located in the external surface and the grafted functional groups are in
close proximity to the pore entrances. Therefore, the grafted materials show relatively greater hydrothermal stability than the cocondensed ones.114
Comparatively, the superior advantage of the cocondensation method is that the functional groups can be evenly distributed throughout the entire material. This is especially true when the functional groups are electrostatically matched with the surfactants. The most attractive aspect of the post-synthesis grafting method is the potential to introduce functional groups on the external surface while the surfactant is still located inside the mesoporous channels. After removal of the surfactant, a second group can be introduced to functionalise the internal surface of the materials.115,116 Selective functionalisation of the external or internal surface of MSNs provide great features and benefits for their biological applications. For example, it showed that mass transfer was enhanced within the mesoporous channels by the participation of functional groups in the internal surface of MSNs,117
while the functionalisation of the particle external surface can be employed for tuning the affinity of materials in different suspension media.118

sections.heading: Functionalisation of pore entrances
sections.text:
One of the most appealing outcomes of functionalisation at pore entrances is to load and release molecules in a controlled fashion. This so-called ‘gated’ systemwas first established on the basis of coumarin molecules, which can mask the pore entrances by the photoactivated dimerisation of the coumarin groups to yield cyclobutane bridges.119
Since then, researchers have developed different kinds of macromolecules and nanoparticles as removable caps that could be anchored at pore entrances for loading and releasing cargos of interest from MSNs. These caps included CdS nanoparticles,120,121 gold nanoparticles,122 iron oxide nanoparticles,123 styrene derivatives,124 cyclodextrin,125–128 rotaxanes and pseudorotaxanes,129–132 polyamines133,134 and proteins.135–137 For the choice of caps, it has been shown that solid nanoparticle caps are more effective for fast release of small amounts of cargos, while flexible macromolecular caps are more adequate for the sustained release of large amount of cargos over relatively long periods of time.121
8 Introduction of functional groups in different regions of MSNs: a at the external surface; b at the pore entrances and c within the pore walls
International Materials Reviews 2016 7

sections.heading: Functionalisation of pore wall
sections.text:
The main advantage of introducing any functionality within the pore walls of MSNs is that the functional groups will not partially block the mesopores. This allows for a better diffusion of the molecules of interest through the pore channels when using the material. Mesoporous silica nanostructures containing organic groups in their walls are better known as periodic mesoporous organosilicas (PMOs). Since the introduced groups are expected to conform to the framework of MSNs, they usually affect the hydrophilic-hydrophobic balance of the system. This phenomenon makes it more difficult to tune the synthetic conditions to simultaneously obtain well-ordered pore channels and particle size and shape of interest. This is also the reason for the limited number of regularly formed PMOs found in the previous literatures. To date, different metals have been incorporated into the pore wall of mesoporous silica structures, common elements found in the mesoporous silica matrices are aluminium,138 iron,139 titanium,140 and gadolinium.141 However, it is noted that the introduction of metals usually leads to some decrease in the order of mesophase.
Roles of particle size, shape and surface chemistry on biological systems The structural properties of MSNs, namely particle size and shape, can be precisely tailored during their initial synthesis. These characteristics enable the functionalisation at specific regions of the nanomaterials. The precise control of these physiochemical properties renders MSNs as highly specialised nanodevices for various biological applications. Introduction of specialised biomaterials of the literature, such as hydroxylapatite, bioglass, biodegradable polymer and asbestos, are already available.142–153 Here, we will focus the specific interactions of size, shape and surface chemistry of MSNs with biological systems. These issues include but are not limited to: cellular uptake, in vitro and in vivo biocompatibility and site-specific delivery. Through a direct comparison of parallel experiments from previous literatures, we can clearly get a measure of how particle size, shape and surface chemistry can be tailored to be more effective in biological applications.

sections.heading: Cellular uptake
sections.text: The transmembrane transport and concomitant cellular uptake abilities of MSNs are the prerequisite to exert their roles in biological systems, especially drug delivery, cells-/bacteria-killing and tumour targeting. The understanding of the effects of physiochemical properties on cellular uptake behaviours, such as uptake kinetics and endocytosis mechanism, is necessary and important to allow manipulation of the translocation of MSNs in a controlled manner.

sections.heading: Cellular uptake kinetics
sections.text:
Since the initial investigation of the interactions of MSNs with cells, researchers are aware of the possible effects that particle size, shape and surface chemistry could have on the cellular uptake kinetics of nanomaterials. The effect of particle size on the cellular uptake of MSNs was first
revealed by using mesoporous silica nano- (270 nm) and micro- particles (2.5 μm) on human phagocyte cells (monocyte-derived dendritic cells). More dendritic containing MSNs were observed for larger-sized particles than for smaller-sized particles.14 However, when examined MSNs with particle size ranging from 30 to 280 nm on Hela cells, the size-dependent uptake behaviour was clearly present and the maximum uptake after 5 h of incubation occurs at a nanoparticle size of 50 nm (Fig. 9a).8 This result was consistent with the finding that 50 nm and smaller size MSNs are favoured for uptake by Hela cells after 4–24 h of incubation.12 In addition, by treatment of MDA-MB-468 cells with particle size of 190, 420 and 1220 nm, size-dependent uptake behaviour was also shown and MSNs of smaller size can be more easily uptaken by cells.154 Therefore, based on the current observations, it seems that phagocytic cells favour to capture large micrometer-sized particles, while nonphagocytic cells show a tendency to uptake small nanometer-sized materials. From theoretical perspectives, various predictions from
computational models have already suggested that particle shape plays significant roles on the cellular binding and transmembrane transport abilities of nanoparticles.155–160 Experimentally, using spherical and rodshaped MSNs of different ARs, shape-dependent cellular uptake was found and MSNs with larger ARs could be taken up in higher amounts and at faster internalisation rates by A375 cells and Hela cells (Fig. 9b).36,42,43 However, contradictory results can be also found. In one study, when the uptake behaviours of spherical and rodshaped MSNs by CHO cells and human fibroblast cells were tested, shape-independent uptake kinetics were found in CHO cells and the uptake rate of spherical MSNs by human fibroblast cells was significantly faster than that of rod-shaped MSNs.41 In another study, it was shown that rod-shaped MSNs with ARs at around two exhibited the highest uptake rates by A549 cells than other MSNs with larger or smaller ARs.34 These results showed that the interactions of MSNs and cells may vary among different cell types and origins. This is an important issue for consideration when constructing personalised biological nanodevices. To explore the effect of surface chemistry on cellular
uptake performance, it should be kept in mind that one notable feature of cell membrane is its net negative surface charge. Therefore, either the surface potential of MSNs or attaching cell membrane receptors to its surface can affect the cellular uptake kinetics. Considering these properties, the charge effect on the uptake of MSNs by Hela cells was first examined with materials possessing either amine or guanidine functionalities. A trend was discovered in the internalisation of MSNs related to the surface charge. The values for the effective dose at 50% of internalisation (ED50) of these MSNs increased with the increase in the negative value of their surface charge (Fig. 9c).161 The surface charge-dependent cellular uptake of MSNs can be also found in phagocytic RAW264.7 cells and nonphagocytic A549 cells.35 However, not all cell types exhibited this surface charge-dependent cellular uptake behaviour. For example, a correlation between the positive charge of MSNs and internalisation into 3T3-L1 cells was found, whereas, no correlation was observed in hMSCs cells.162 These indicated that such surface charge effect could be varied by cell types and cell origins.
8 International Materials Reviews 2016
Functionalisation of MSNs surface with cell receptor specific groups, such as folic acid,161,163 is another alternative strategy to enhance the cellular uptake abilities. In addition, polyethylene glycol (PEG)164–166 and lipid molecules (DOPC, POPC, DPPC and DSPC)167–169 are also commonly used to coat the surface of MSNs for enhancing the transmembrane transport efficiency. It should be reminded that, when we tried to examine
the specific cellular uptake activities of nanomaterials, its dispersion status is also quite important. To date, more and more evidence showed that nanomaterials can be induced to aggregation to a certain extent by many internal and external factors, such as zeta potential of nanomaterials, temperature and suspending medium contents. This phenomenon will probably affect the performance of nanomaterials when they meet with cells.

sections.heading: Cellular uptake mechanism
sections.text:
Cell membrane is a very complex system that consists mainly of lipids, proteins, cholesterol and receptors. To regulate the cellular uptake efficiency of MSNs, one should have detailed information regarding how particles can interact with cell membrane and then translocate into cells, andwhat is their subsequent fate inside of cells. Aiming for these, researchers shifted their attention to explore the endocytosis mechanism of nanomaterials. Generally, endocytosis can be divided into four major categories: (1) Phagocytosis, which is executed by specialised professional phagocytes (such as monocytes, kupffer cells, macrophages and neutrophiles). (2) Clathrin-dependent endocytosis, which is involved in clathrin-coated vesicles
that can be subsequently transformed to endosomes. A fraction of internalised particles would be recycled back to the exterior, while the remaining fractions are transferred into lysosomes. (3) Caveolae-dependent endocytosis, which is typically characterised by the evolution of caveolae-derivatives of the subdomains of sphingolipid and cholesterol-rich cell membrane fractions. After internalisation, the particles would be transported to caveosomes and then either translocated to the endoplasmic reticulum/Golgi body or entered into the endosomal pathway. (4) Clathrin- and caveolae-independent endocytosis, which include those pathways not usually classified by the above criteria, such as actin-, flotillin- and Arf6dependent pathways. All these pathways are generally energy-dependent and involve active formation of membrane invaginations, membrane ruffles and transport vesicles.170–173 With respect to their physiochemical features, nanoparticles can be internalised into cell through various endocytosis pathways, such as phagocytosis and pinocytosis. Phagocytosis is typically restricted to specialised mammalian cells, whereas pinocytosis occurs in all cells and is known as fluid-phase uptake pathway. Even in the cases where phagocytosis of nanoparticles is to be avoided, non-phagocytosis of these materials by desired cells can be critical to their biological performance. Non-phagocytic cells, such as Hela cells, A549 cells, CHO cells and hMSCs, will likely internalise these nanoparticles via endocytosis or pinocytosis pathways. To study the endocytosis mechanism of nanomaterials,
there are two commonly used strategies: endocytosis inhibitors for exclusion of specific endocytosis pathway and endocytosis markers for colocalisation and tracking

of nanomaterials. Based on these two strategies, the roles of particle size, shape and surface chemistry of MSNs on endocytosis mechanism can be revealed. To date, the interaction of the size ofMSNswith cellular uptake mechanism has still not been fully determined. However, there are studies showing that internalisation of smaller size particles in non-phagocytic B16 cells involved the clathrin-dependent pathway, with increasing particle size, a shift to a mechanism that relied on caveolae-mediated endocytosis became apparent.174 The shape effect of MSNs on cellular uptake mechanism was first demonstrated using spherical and rod-shaped MSNs of different ARs on Hela cells. It was shown that sphericalMSNs favoured to be internalised via the clathrin-dependent endocytosis pathway and the caveolae-dependent endocytosis pathway became predominant when the ARs of MSNs increased (Fig. 10).42 Surface chemistry have been also demonstrated to play significant roles on the cellular uptake mechanism of MSNs. Using different functional groups-grafted MSNs for treatment of Hela cells, it was found that N-folate-3aminopropyl functionalisation can lead to a clathrindependent endocytosis pathway, 3-aminopropyl or guanidinopropyl functionalisation can result in caveolaedependent endocytosis pathway and 3-[N-(2-guanidinoethyl)guanidino]propyl functionalisation could cause clathrin- and caveolae-independent endocytosis.161 Interesting results also showed that the surface chemistry effect is cell-type-dependent. For example, a correlation was found between surface chemistry of MSNs and cellular uptake mechanism into 3T3-L1 cells, but this correlation was not observed in hMSCs cells.162 Same as mentioned above, besides particle size, shape and surface chemistry, many other factors, such as dispersion status, zeta potential
and pore size and shape, should also be carefully considered when we tried to probe the specific cellular uptake mechanism of nanomaterials.

sections.heading: Biocompatibility
sections.text: For biological applications, MSNs should meet the basic prerequisites of both performing desired functions and also avoiding any adverse effects to the body. Therefore, establishing the effects of the physiochemical properties of MSNs on biocompatibility is an urgent necessity. Recently, the biocompatibility studies on MSNs involving in vitro cytotoxicity, biodegradation, in vivo biodistribution, excretion and tissue compatibility are drawing great attention.

sections.heading: Cytotoxicity
sections.text:
The initial biocompatibility test of MSNs always consists of cellular experiments. Although such in vitro tests have only limited significance for the situation in vivo, they can detect toxicity and thus may help to reduce the number of animal experiments. However, considering the diversity of cell types and treatments, it can be seen that the cytotoxicity results from previous literatures are always not in agreement with each other. Recent views on the size effect of MSNs on cytotox-
icity can be categorised into three aspects: (1) Smaller size particles have lower cytotoxicity. For example, when treated human phagocyte cells (monocyte-derived dendritic cells) with mesoporous silica nano- (270 nm) and micro-particles (2.5 μm), size-dependent phenomenon was observed where smaller-sized silica particles affected cells to a minor degree compared to the

sections.heading: 10 Effect of particle shape of MSNs on endocytosis mechanism in Hela cells. Particles with smaller ARs favoured the clathrindependent endocytosis pathway and particles with larger ARs preferred the caveolae-dependent endocytosis pathway.
sections.text:
Reproduced with permission from Hao et al.42
10 International Materials Reviews 2016
larger-sized particles, both in terms of viability and immune regulatory markers, which was seen by the induction of IL-12p70 and CD86 and a decreased expression of CD80 and CD40.14 (2) Smaller size particles have higher cytotoxicity. This viewpoint has gained relatively more support from recent studies. For examples, one study found that smaller MSNs exhibited higher haemolytic activity because they employed higher density of silanol group and thus have potentially increased contactable surface with red blood cells (Fig. 11a).10 Another study also showed that 190 nm and 420 nm particles have significant cytotoxicity on COS7 and MDA-MB-468 cells at concentrations above 25 μg mL−1, while 1220 nm particles almost always show slight cytotoxicity over a broad concentration range of 10–480 μg mL−1.154 (3) Size has no effect on cytotoxicity. This viewpoint has also gained certain evidences, especially from those studies involving good
cellular biocompatibility of different particle size ranges. For example, when treated Hela cells with MSNs of size from 25 to 105 nm, the cell viability remained above 80% even with particle concentration up to 1 mg mL−1 and no size-dependent cytotoxicity was found.12
Similar to particle size of MSNs, the findings of the particle shape effect on cytotoxicity also differ from each other. Using spherical and rod-shaped MSNs of different ARs on A375 human melanoma cells, it was found that non-spherical rod-shaped MSNs, especially particles with larger ARs, had a much greater impact on different aspects of cell functions, including cell proliferation, apoptosis, cytoskeleton formation, adhesion and migration, than their spherical counterparts (Fig. 11b– d).43 However, when RAW 264.7 macrophage cells, A549 cells and human red blood cells were treated with spherical and rod-shaped MSNs of different ARs from 1 to 8, researchers found that particles with larger ARs
11 The effect of particle size A, shape B–D, and surface chemistry E on cytotoxicity activities. A Photographs of haemolysis of human red blood cells incubated with four sizes of MSNs. The presence of red haemoglobin in the supernatant indicates damaged cells. D.I. water (+) and PBS (−) are used as positive and negative control, respectively. B–D Effect of particle shape on cytoskeleton formation B, adhesion C and migration D of A375 cells. NS, NSR and NLR indicate sphere, shortrod and long-rod MSNs, respectively. E Photographs of haemolysis of human red blood cells incubated with PEGylated MSNs. Reproduced with permission from Lin and Haynes10 and Huang et al.43
International Materials Reviews 2016 11
could lead to lower haemolytic activity, and no obvious shape-dependent cytotoxicity on RAW 264.7 cells and A549 cells was found.35 This shape-independent cytotoxicity behaviour was also found in Hela cells that treated with spherical and rod-shaped MSNs.26
In contrast to particle size and shape, the effect of surface chemistry of MSNs on cytotoxicity is much more clear. Generally, some of the main outcomes reported in these studies are that: (1) Functionalisation ofMSNs, to a certain degree, could decrease the cytotoxicity ofMSNs.175 (2) Surface charge significantly regulated the cytotoxicity of MSNs, the higher positive charge they possess, the more toxicity they have.35 (3) Surface PEGylation could reduce the cytotoxicity of MSNs (Fig. 11e).10,165,176,177 (4) Cytotoxicity activity of MSNs is related to surface silanol groups.10,178
These preliminary results from in vitro toxicity studies demonstrated that the effect of the physiochemical properties of MSNs on cytotoxicity may be varied or complicated from cell origins and features,26 surfactant removal methods,154 culturing media components, incubation time and particle concentrations.36,179 Therefore, a general and mature system should be established to exactly tell the specific roles of particle size, shape and surface chemistry on cytotoxicity activities.

sections.heading: Biodegradation
sections.text:
Degradability of MSNs is a key point that needs to be considered not only for evaluating the activity of payload drugs, but also for their potential toxic considerations of
degradation products on the body. There are limited reports on the effect of particle size on biodegradation. When testing MSNs with different sizes (ca. 20–80 nm) in phosphate buffer saline (PBS, pH 7.3), it was found that the degradation rates of MSNs are independent of the difference in particle size.17 In contrast to particle size, particle shape has been demonstrated to play significant roles in tuning the degradation kinetics of MSNs. Using spherical and rod-shaped MSNs of different ARs, it was found that, no matter in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Medium (DMEM) or serum proteins-enriched DMEM systems, spherical particles have a faster degradation rate than rod-shaped particles and the larger the particle ARs, the slower the degradation rate.180 Similar shape-dependent degradation behaviour was also found when testing MSNs of different ARs in simulated gastric fluid, simulated body fluid and simulated intestinal fluid (Fig. 12a–b).181 Surface functionalisation can also tailor the degradation kinetics of mesoporous silica structures. For example, after modification with alkyl chains (methyl and octyl) or aminopropyl groups, the degradation of MSNs in saline solution (pH 7.4), simulated body fluid and completed DMEM, tended to slow down.182 There is also ample evidence that surface PEGylation can significantly reduce the degradation rate of MSNs, and the higher the molecular weight of PEG, the slower the rate of degradation (Fig. 12c).177,183,184 Interestingly, one study found that surface PEGylation could alter the degradation origination sites from particle external surface to particle interior.180 Importantly, in addition to
12 The effect of particle shape A–B and surface chemistry C on biodegradation kinetics. A and B are TEM images and calculated degradation rate of different-shaped MSNs after degradation for 7 d. a, d, g samples in simulated gastric fluid; b, e, h samples in simulated intestinal fluid; c, f, i samples in simulated body fluid. NS, NSR and NLR indicate sphere, short-rod and long-rod MSNs, respectively. C SEM images of the mesoporous silica particles during the degradation process in PBS pH 7.2. Systems shown: a Particles modified with 3-APTES; b Particles modified with PEG 861; c Particles modified with PEG 5000. Time points: 2, 8, 18 and 48 h. Reproduced with permission from Slowing et al.178 and Izquierdo-Barba et al.182
12 International Materials Reviews 2016
particle size, shape and surface chemistry, there are also many other factors that can affect the degradation behaviour of MSNs, such as surfactant removal method,185 local fluid flow conditions,186 pore size,187 administration routes,188 and particle dispersion and aggregation status.17
Biodistribution, excretion and tissue compatibility
To best minimise their toxicity and side effects, MSNs should meet the requirements of either being degraded in situ into truly non-toxic subcomponents or being excreted from the body, once they have served their theranostic purposes. Therefore, systematically investigation of relationships between physiochemical properties of MSNs and in vivo biocompatibility, including biodistribution, excretion and tissue compatibility, is considered to be significantly important. By tail-vein injection of different-sized MSNs (80–360 nm) in ICR mice, it was found that MSNs were mainly located in liver and spleen, a minority of them in lung, a few in kidney and heart and larger particle size can be more easily captured by these organs. Excreted quantities of MSNs also have a positive correlation with their particle size (Fig. 13a–b). Compared with the normal control, all treated tissues (heart, liver, spleen, lung and kidney) showed no acute pathological injury and inflammation during 1 month in vivo.15 Particle shape of MSNs also showed important roles on biodistribution, excretion and biocompatibility in vivo. For example, organic distributions showed that intravenously administrated MSNs of different ARs (1.5 and 5) are mainly present in the liver, spleen and lung (>80%) and there are obvious particle shape effects on in vivo behaviours. Short-rod MSNs are easily trapped in the liver, while long-rod MSNs distribute in the spleen. The excretion rate of MSNs via urine and faeces is also
primarily dependent on the particle shape, where shortrod MSNs have a more rapid excretion rate than longrod MSNs in both excretion routes. Histopathology results indicated that both types of MSNs would not cause significant toxicity in vivo, which is in agreement with the above size-related investigations (Fig. 13c–e).44
Further evidence showed that particle shape of MSNs, regardless of their administration routes, governed the in vivo biodistribution, excretion and toxicity.181 Surface charge as an important parameter of surface chemistry of MSNs could remarkably impact the in vivo biocompatibility of MSNs. It is shown that amine-functionalised MSNs with a highly positive charge underwent rapid transport from the liver into the gastrointestinal tract and subsequent hepatobiliary elimination into faeces within 30 min of tail-vein injection to male nude mice. However, the MSNs with a highly negative charge remained sequestered within the liver for more than 3 months, further investigations indicated that the sequestered MSNs are largely concentrated within the intracellular vesicles of Kupffer cells.189 Surface PEGylation is another effective strategy to tune the in vivo behaviour of MSNs. PEGylated particles generally could escape more easily from capture by liver and spleen, possess longer blood-circulation lifetime and have a lower excreted amount (Fig. 13).15,44 It is noted that the dispersibility of tested nanomaterials is critical when examined their in vivo behaviours, including biodistribution, excretion and tissue compatibility. Minor or severe aggregation could obviously lead to adverse effects on bodies to some extent.

sections.heading: Targeted drug delivery
sections.text:
The combination of drug delivery and targeting transportation to specific organelle/tissue populations is a key
13 The effect of particle size, shape, and surface chemistry on in vivo biodistribution, excretion and tissue compatibility. A Comparisons of the biodistribution of MSNs and PEG–MSNs of different particle sizes (80, 120, 200 and 360 nm) in liver a and spleen b of ICR mice 30 min after tail intravenous injection. B Excretion percentages of MSNs and PEG–MSNs of different particle sizes in urine of ICR mice up to 1 month after tail intravenous injection. C Quantitative analysis of differentshaped MSNs in organs and blood by ICP-OES. Relative Si contents in liver, spleen and kidney at 2 h a, 24 h b and 7 d c post-injection. D ICP-OES quantitative analysis of the Si content in urine a, and faeces b at 2 h, 24 h and 7d after injection. E Effect of different-shaped MSNs on histopathology of the liver, spleen, lung and kidney at 7 d after intravenous injection. NSR and NLR indicate short-rod and long-rod MSNs, respectively. Reproduced with permission from He et al.15 and Huang et al.44
International Materials Reviews 2016 13
issue in biomedical science. Targeted drug delivery systems, which are expected to enhance the therapeutic efficiency while simultaneously reducing the toxic side effects, have drawn great attention in the last several years. Different strategies have been used for targeting delivery, such as chemically attached antibodies, peptides, sugars, proteins or specific ligands to MSNs carriers. In this section, we will put our focus on the effect of particle size, shape and surface chemistry of MSNs on several aspects of targeting drug delivery systems, including drug loading and releasing, organelle-specific targeting and tumour targeting.

sections.heading: Drug loading and releasing
sections.text:
Since 2001, when MSNs were first proposed as controlled drug delivery system,190 they have been intensively investigated and demonstrated to be important alternative drug carriers. Various kinds of medical molecules, such as pharmaceutical drugs,191,192 peptides and proteins,193,194 and genes,195,196 have been successfully utilised MSNs as ‘reservoir’ and then released to animal cells, plant cells or bacteria. Different stimuli-responsive drug releasing systems in response to temperature,197 radiation,192 electronic field,198 magnetic field,199 ultrasound,200 pH,201 redox,202 and enzymes,135 have also been developed for achieving ‘zero premature release’ before being transferred to desired locations.However, the effect of physiochemical properties of MSNs on drug loading and releasing performance has still not gained enough attention. The size effect ofMSNs on drug loading capacity is gen-
erally obvious, the smaller the particle size the higher the loading capacity. This can be attributed to shorter pore channels of smaller nanoparticles, which will reduce the possibility of pore blocking by drugs.193 However, drug releasing may not display size-dependent profile when tested in in vitro media.12 As evidenced by particle size, different-shaped MSNs with relatively short channels, such as ellipsoidal-shaped particles with pore channels running along the short axis,67,70 sheet-shaped particles with channels normal to the surface,103 and film-shaped particles with perpendicularly aligned channels,77,93
showed excellent drug loading and releasing performance. For rod-shaped MSNs with different ARs, shape-dependent drug release was also found, and the larger the ARs of MSNs, the slower the rate of drug release.39 The effect of surface chemistry of MSNs on drug loading and releasing ismuchmore complex, especiallywhen considering the spatial structures and densities of functionalisation moieties. There are studies showed that surface modification had a negligible influence on the capacity of drug loading and releasing.12 However, contrary results can be also found in respect of the surface chemistry-dependent drug loading amount and releasing rate.164,191,203 In addition to particle size, shape and surface chemistry, several other important parameters, such as pore size, zeta potential, testedmedia and conditions, particle dispersion status and the physiochemical properties of drugs, should be also consideredwhen evaluating the drug loading and releasing behaviours of MSNs.
Organelle-specific targeting
Most of the current MSNs-based delivery systems are not designed to target specific organelles into the cell. In order to better drive their intracellular distribution and deliver
their cargos at specific organelles, surface decoration of MSNs with organelle-specific targeting moieties is generally necessary and desirable. Peptides that are recognised by the cytosolic transport systems, such as nuclear localisation signal, mitochondrial localisation signal and endoplasmic reticulum signal, are main category of such targeting moieties.204,205 There are also molecules that are known for their tropism or specific interactions toward the membrane of a specific organelle that have been employed in targeting delivery strategies, such as dexamethasone and triamcinolone acetonide for nuclear-targeting, and triphenylphosphonium for mitochondria-targeting. Obviously, the targeting delivery efficiency of MSNs
will be significantly affected by the presentation of surface targeting moieties, which is dominated by particle size and shape. Using TAT peptide-modified MSNs of different sizes (25–105 nm), it was shown that the presence of TAT peptide facilitated the active nuclear entry of MSNs through the nuclear, while the size of the MSNsTAT is a critical factor in the translocation. 25–50 nmsized MSNs conjugated with TAT peptide has been proven to more efficiently target the nucleus and deliver the active anticancer drug doxorubicin (DOX) into the targeted nucleus, killing these cancer cells with much enhanced efficiencies.12 Compared to their spherical counterparts, non-spherical MSNs displayed superior advantages in organelle delivery by the aid of targeting moieties. For example, when conjugated with trehalose as the targeting ligand, the antibiotic-encapsulated ellipsoid-shaped MSNs exhibited high cell wall binding affinity toward mycobacteria,70 and the antibacterial efficacy was greater than their spherical counterparts.45
Evidences also showed that cytochromium c-specific binding DNA aptamer or triphenylphosphonium cation could be employed to make non-spherical rod-shaped MSNs efficiently accumulate in the mitochondria of cancer cells.206,207 To date, several kinds of MSNs-based organelle-targeting delivery systems have been emerged. However, there are still remain many issues to be solved, such as the optimisation of the targeting ligands, the effect of surface modification density on targeting efficiency, the stability and activity changes of the targeting ligands after modified on particle surface, the interaction of organelle with MSNs and their subsequent fate.

sections.heading: Tumour targeting
sections.text:
Tumour is currently one of the most challenging human health diseases, which obliges researchers tirelessly to develop new routes for tumour therapy. Recent advances in nanotechnology provide a promising alternative by reducing side effects and improving efficacy.208–210 Generally, for MSNs-based tumour therapy systems, there are two major challenges to achieving sufficiently local drug concentrations in desired tumour location. One is evading the sequestration of reticuloendothelial system (RES) from the circulation (Fig. 14a–b), and the other is extravasating from the vasculature into the interstitial space of solid tumour tissue for following interactions with tumour cells (Fig. 14c–d). For the former issue, the keypoint is designing ‘stealth’ particles that can escape the opsonisation of RES and thus have a longer blood-circulation time. Surface PEGylation has been demonstrated to be the most efficient strategy to yield ‘stealth’ architectures.
14 International Materials Reviews 2016
In addition, MSNs with relatively larger size or ARs also showed excellent abilities to prevent MSNs from being captured by RES and lead to relatively longer blood-circulation time.15,44 The latter issue is associated with the so-called ‘enhanced permeability and retention (EPR)’ effect, which is a consequence of the poorly developed lymphatic system and the aberrant features of tumour vasculature that limits drainage of molecules or particles from tumour tissue.211 These abnormal physiological properties of tumour endow substantial advantages to MSNs-based theranostic systems for passive tumour targeting.212 This process is no doubt affected by the physiochemical properties of MSNs, it is shown that smallersized, non-spherical-shaped and low-density surface functionalised particles are more favourable for many EPRrelated aspects, such as vascular margination and tumour tissue deep penetration.159,213,214 Combined with the above observations, it is likely that design of multistage mesoporous silica delivery system is much more practical and effective for passive tumour targeting.214 However, even with the EPR effect, difficulties still exist for further increasing the efficiency of passive targeting through overcoming the unique physiological properties of tumour, such as elevated intratumoural interstitial pressure, dense extracellular matrix and the existence of poorly perfused hypoxic regions. These limitations of passive tumour targeting has promoted the research and development of more advanced active tumour targeting, which is achieved by the surface functionalisation of targeting moieties. There are two main categories of molecular targets for active tumour targeting: tumour cell membrane receptors, such as transferring receptors, folic acid receptors and epidermal growth factor receptor, and tumour
vasculature receptors, such as vascular endothelial growth factor receptor, vascular cell adhesion molecule receptor and αβ-integrins.215 For both passive targeting and active targeting strategies, the physiochemical properties of MSNs are shown to exert great influence on their performance to overcome the in vivo philological barriers, reach tumour tissue, bind and interact with target tumour cells and release cargo inside cells.

sections.heading: Summary and future perspectives
sections.text:
Mesoporous silica-based particulate system has been an exciting topic of research in multiple biological areas. A most appealing part of MSNs is that we can regulate their physiochemical properties during the synthesis process. In this context, it is essential to understand how the physiochemical properties of MSNs interact with subcellular organelles, cells, tissues and organisms. In this review, we highlighted recent studies on how mesoporous silica structures with controlled size, shape and surface chemistry can be synthesised, and how particle size, shape and surface chemistry of MSNs affect their performance on cellular uptake, in vitro and in vivo biocompatibility and targeted drug delivery. With deeper understanding of these roles via theoretical and experimental studies, along with establishment of robust engineering technologies for large scale production of MSNs with well-defined structural and surface properties, the future generation of mesoporous silica-based nanocarriers is expected to have superior efficacy in maintaining optimal binding and retention at target site, biosafety and controlled release of cargos payload.
14 Schematic illustration of in vivo tumour delivery of MSNs-based targeting systems after systematic administration
International Materials Reviews 2016 15
Emerging evidences showed that these physiochemical properties of MSNs play important roles in influencing particle behaviour in biological systems in terms of cellular uptake kinetics and mechanism, cytotoxicity, biodegradation, biodistribution, excretion, tissue compatibility, drug loading and releasing, organelle-specific targeting and tumour targeting. With deeper insights into these aspects, it is imperative that the scientific community focuses on systematic research, where each of these design parameters can be independently studied over a broad range. However, large scale comparative studies of this kind are still currently lacking. Carrying out such studies will enable a thorough comparison of the various parameters toward identifying the optimal design of the future generations of mesoporous silica-based nanocarriers. Further advancement in such mesoporous silica nanosystems can be envisioned via development of multistage and multiscale materials, where the size, shape and surface chemistry of MSNs can be fine-tuned in response to various stimulis, such as pH, temperature, redox, enzyme and shear. In order to establish the ideal physiochemical design of MSNs, appropriate theoretical and experimental studies need to be designed that can span the ranges of scales, geometries and charges from nano-to-micro, from sphereto-rod-to-ellipsoid-to-all other possible shapes, and from negative-to-neutral-to-positive such that proper comparisons can be carried out and the identified platforms can be realistically translated to practical theranostic use. A truly interdisciplinary effort between researchers from the fields of materials, engineering, chemistry, physics, biology and mathematics is needed to realise this vision of the next generation of mesoporous silica-based nanocarriers. While envisaging the future perspectives in light of the
present review, it can be seen that (1) Compared to wellestablished biomaterials platforms, such as hydroxylapatite, bioglass, polymer and asbestos, the synthesis and application of mesoporous silica materials are still in their infancy. There is plenty of room available to develop new routes for easy synthesis of mesoporous silica structures and their breakthrough applications. (2)High quality mesoporous silica materials with controlled physiochemical properties, such aswell dispersion status (non-agglomeration), uniform structure and high scalability and repeatability, are still urgently needed. Synthesis strategies and formation mechanism toward these materials are not yet fully optimised. (3) Besides particle size, shape, surface chemistry, there are still manyother factors influencing the biological performance of mesoporous silica materials on the above-mentioned aspects. These factors included but not limited to pore properties, zeta potential, surface area ratio, particle dispersion status, suspending medium contents, working temperature, cell types and cell origins and administration routes. For example, pore size and pore type directly affect the payload capacity and releasing kinetics of theranostic agents,216,217 the difference on the cytotoxicity was also found to be caused by the pores of silica nanomaterials.10 Zeta potential of MSNs not only affects their dispersion status,42 but also determines their in vitro and in vivo biological performance.44,162,189 From the viewpoint of surface area ratio, a dose-effect relationship between MSNs and biological systems can be clearly reflected.218–220 The content of testing medium was also found playing significant roles on the dispersion status of nanomaterials and the cellular uptake kinetics.36,42,179 (4) There is still lack of a comprehensive understanding on
nano–bio interactions. For example, the investigation objects of cell and animal types are very limited, and direct parallel comparison studies are relatively rare. (5) Researchers have already made some progress from their laboratory scale studies, but far from enough, unless it is used on an industrial scale for the final real practical products. When these issues solved, in the coming years, it is expected that mesoporous silica materials could help for developing a series of bio-related products, such as pharmaceuticals, biosensors, diagnosis tool and treatment regimen.We thus hope that mesoporous silicamaterialswould play beneficial roles in human health.

referenceMentions.context: MSNs are generally synthesised by a surfactant-directing method under basic, acidic or neutral conditions.(7) Silica precursors are first hydrolyzed and then combined with the surfactant micelles by either electrostatic force or hydrogen bond interaction to form a liquid-crystal mesophase.

Silica precursors are first hydrolyzed and then combined with the surfactant micelles by either electrostatic force or hydrogen bond interaction to form a liquid-crystal mesophase.(6) The transformation of mesophase occurs during the hydrolysis and cocondensation of silica precursors.

Along with size, particle shape is another interesting design parameter that should be taken into consideration.(19,20) However, due to limited availability of strategies and techniques, the research and development of different-shaped MSNs has relatively lagged behind.

In addition, ellipsoid-shaped particles have already shown great promise in the design of drug carrier systems.(63,64) However, the controlled synthesis of ellipsoid-shaped MSNs is still a big challenge because of the minimisation of surface free energy that usually favours general spherical shapes.

This method generally uses ellipsoidtype haematite or β-FeOOH nanoparticles as templates, after coating with silica layer, the templates are then selectively etched out in acidic solution to produce hollow ellipsoid-shaped nanostructures.(73,74) (2) Soft template method.

This method generally uses ellipsoidtype haematite or β-FeOOH nanoparticles as templates, after coating with silica layer, the templates are then selectively etched out in acidic solution to produce hollow ellipsoid-shaped nanostructures.(73,74) (2) Soft template method.

In recent years, film-shaped MSNs have attracted a lot of interests because of their specific applications in biomedical implants, optoelectronic devices, sensors and functional membranes.(77) It thus makes great sense to synthesise film-shaped mesoporous silica that have ordered mesostructures and high porosity, yet are mechanically strong enough and allow selective but free transportation of materials through the films.

Generally, using glass or silica wafer as solid substrate, film-shaped MSNs can be formed by air–liquid interfaces assembly,(78,79) spin-/dip-coating methods,(80,81) or the evaporation-induced self-assembly approach.(82) However, because the surfactantmicelles always tend to orient parallel to substrates to reduce the surface energy at interfaces, the obtained film products from these strategies are usually composed ofmesochannels that are oriented parallel to the film surface.

However, because the surfactantmicelles always tend to orient parallel to substrates to reduce the surface energy at interfaces, the obtained film products from these strategies are usually composed ofmesochannels that are oriented parallel to the film surface.(83) For obtaining well-defined film-shaped MSNs with perpendicularly aligned channels, a series of established systems were applied in recent studies, which included self-assembly of block copolymers or gemini surfactants with organosilane,(84,85) employment of electric fields,(86) magnetic fields,(87) electrochemical assistance,(88) nanophase separation of eutectic materials,(89) Stöber approach,(90) surface modification for confinement effects,(91) π–π interaction of template molecules,(92) and cosurfactant system.

25–50 nmsized MSNs conjugated with TAT peptide has been proven to more efficiently target the nucleus and deliver the active anticancer drug doxorubicin (DOX) into the targeted nucleus, killing these cancer cells with much enhanced efficiencies.(12) Compared to their spherical counterparts, non-spherical MSNs displayed superior advantages in organelle delivery by the aid of targeting moieties.

For example, when conjugated with trehalose as the targeting ligand, the antibiotic-encapsulated ellipsoid-shaped MSNs exhibited high cell wall binding affinity toward mycobacteria,(70) and the antibacterial efficacy was greater than their spherical counterparts.(45) Evidences also showed that cytochromium c-specific binding DNA aptamer or triphenylphosphonium cation could be employed to make non-spherical rod-shaped MSNs efficiently accumulate in the mitochondria of cancer cells.

Combined with the above observations, it is likely that design of multistage mesoporous silica delivery system is much more practical and effective for passive tumour targeting.(214) However, even with the EPR effect, difficulties still exist for further increasing the efficiency of passive targeting through overcoming the unique physiological properties of tumour, such as elevated intratumoural interstitial pressure, dense extracellular matrix and the existence of poorly perfused hypoxic regions.

There are two main categories of molecular targets for active tumour targeting: tumour cell membrane receptors, such as transferring receptors, folic acid receptors and epidermal growth factor receptor, and tumour vasculature receptors, such as vascular endothelial growth factor receptor, vascular cell adhesion molecule receptor and αβ-integrins.(215) For both passive targeting and active targeting strategies, the physiochemical properties of MSNs are shown to exert great influence on their performance to overcome the in vivo philological barriers, reach tumour tissue, bind and interact with target tumour cells and release cargo inside cells.
